question: What is the rationale for the study (one or more expected answers)?

answers.a: death or cardiac arrest from hypoxemia occurs in 40% of tracheal intubation procedures
answers.b: the effectiveness of mask ventilation is debated in the treatment of aspiration pneumonia
answers.c: the benefit-risk ratio of mask ventilation before intubation has long been debated
answers.d: intubation is a frequently performed procedure in the hospital
answers.e: recommendations are contradictory regarding mask ventilation before tracheal intubation

question: Regarding the study population (one or more expected answers):

answers.a: a patient intubated for cardiac arrest could be included
answers.b: a patient with risk factors for aspiration was ineligible
answers.c: randomization made it possible to avoid the subjective choice of patients ventilated with a mask
answers.d: a patient with hematemesis was secondarily excluded
answers.e: a patient intubated in the pre-hospital setting was eligible

question: This is a study (one or more expected answers):

answers.e: with prior collection of informed consent

question: The strengths of randomization in this open-label trial include (one or more expected answers):

answers.a: the use of sealed and numbered opaque envelopes
answers.d: the use of a randomization list by site
answers.e: the possibility of randomizing outside the randomization list in case of emergency

question: Regarding the interventions evaluated (one or more expected answers):

answers.a: the decision to use mask ventilation during induction was left to the investigator's initiative
answers.b: mask ventilation was performed in accordance with North American recommendations
answers.c: mask ventilation of a patient in the control group after induction resulted in their exclusion from the study
answers.d: the pre-oxygenation methods performed before randomization may have biased the results of the trial
answers.e: the absence of mask ventilation at the start of induction in the experimental group constituted a protocol violation

question: What are the strengths of the primary outcome (one or more expected answers)?

answers.a: it reflects a clinically relevant desaturation (less than 80%)
answers.c: it is collected blinded to the evaluated intervention
answers.d: it is validated a posteriori by an independent adjudication committee
answers.e: it is identical for both groups

question: Regarding the calculation of the trial's sample size (one or more expected answers):

answers.a: the type II error risk (beta) was set at 10%
answers.b: the frequency of the primary outcome in the control group was taken into account
answers.c: the variability of the primary outcome was taken into account
answers.d: a re-evaluation of the sample size was done during the study
answers.e: the superiority of not using mask ventilation could be tested

question: For what main reason did the data and safety monitoring board re-evaluate the sample size during the trial (only one expected answer)?

answers.a: to maintain the initially planned statistical power given the observed variability of the primary outcome
answers.b: to account for a safety issue regarding the incidence of aspirations
answers.c: to adjust the statistical significance threshold
answers.d: to account for the results of the interim efficacy analysis
answers.e: to confirm the absence of futility of the trial

question: On which essential factor did randomization fail to fulfill its role (only one expected answer)?
In the intention-to-treat analysis of this trial, a patient from the control group who was ventilated with a mask (only one expected answer):

answers.a: was analyzed in the control group
answers.c: was ineligible and should not have been included in the trial
answers.d: was counted as a failure in the control group
answers.e: was analyzed in the mask ventilation group

question: Regarding Figure 1.A. (one or more expected answers):

answers.a: the degree of significance of the test (p = 0.01) is probably a typographical error since the 95% confidence intervals of the primary outcome overlap
answers.b: the majority of patients did not desaturate to less than 90%
answers.d: the asymmetric distribution of the primary outcome justifies the use of medians
answers.e: several patients have the same minimum oxygen saturation value

question: What are the results of the trial concerning the primary outcome (Table 3) (one or more expected answers):

answers.a: the lowest oxygen saturation value is greater than or equal to 96% for half of the patients in the mask ventilation group
answers.b: 3.9 corresponds to the difference in median saturation between the two groups
answers.c: the mean difference in saturation between the two groups is significant because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the neutral value 1.00
answers.d: patients in the no-mask-ventilation group have a 3.9 times higher risk of desaturating than patients ventilated with a mask
answers.e: the percentage of patients who desaturated differs significantly between the two groups (96% versus 93%)

question: What are the results of the trial concerning the other outcomes (Table 3)? (one or more expected answers)

answers.a: the frequency of desaturations below 80% is decreased by about 50% in the mask ventilation group
answers.b: the reduction in the risk of desaturation below 80% with mask ventilation is significant because the 95% confidence interval does not overlap the neutral value 1.00
answers.c: an increased risk of new opacities on the chest X-ray with mask ventilation cannot be ruled out
answers.d: no statistically significant difference is observed for the exploratory safety outcomes between the two groups of the trial
answers.e: no effect of mask ventilation is observed on hospital mortality

question: Regarding Figure 2 (one or more expected answers):

answers.a: mask ventilation is more effective than no mask ventilation, regardless of the oxygen saturation level at induction
answers.b: only patients paralyzed with a depolarizing agent benefit from mask ventilation
answers.c: the oxygen saturation level at induction could be a modifier of the effect of mask ventilation
answers.d: BiPaP within 6 hours before induction is a confounding factor of the effect of mask ventilation
answers.e: there is no benefit to mask ventilating subjects with a body mass index (BMI) greater than or equal to 30 kg/m2 (p = 0.56)

question: Regarding the methodological limitations related to the open-label nature of the study (one or more expected answers):

answers.a: the determination, by an operator, of the lowest oxygen saturation value may have been influenced by knowledge of the randomization group
answers.b: knowledge of the randomization group may have contributed to different pre-oxygenation between the two groups
answers.c: knowledge of the randomization group may have influenced the choice of concomitant therapies and disadvantaged the effectiveness of mask ventilation
answers.d: the intention-to-treat analysis allowed for control of the measurement bias of the primary outcome
answers.e: the induced biases are minimal since the adjusted post-hoc analysis confirms the results of the main analysis

question: What is the most relevant conclusion of this trial (only one expected answer)?

answers.a: mask ventilation during induction improves oxygen saturation and reduces the risk of aspiration
answers.b: mask ventilation during induction improves oxygen saturation at the cost of unacceptable safety in terms of aspiration
answers.c: mask ventilation does not provide more opportunity for patient oxygenation despite the difference in desaturation
answers.d: mask ventilation during induction improves oxygen saturation and could decrease the incidence of severe desaturation episodes (<80%)
answers.e: mask ventilation during induction improves oxygen saturation and reduces the risk of aspiration but has no effect on hospital mortality
